sub_title: Assistant Professor in Clinical Psychology at Erasmus University Rotterdam
summary:
Why do some adolescents develop anxiety disorders, while others do not? And how can we use this knowledge for more effective interventions? 

I study neural and behavioral correlates of attention bias and social stress to answer these questions. I study social and neural moderators of the temperament-anxiety association using Generation R data, as part of my Marie Sklodowska-Curie Actions Individual Fellowship. Before, I was a post-doctoral researcher at the NIMH with Dr. Daniel Pine and Prof. Nathan Fox. I led several fMRI and behavioral studies with children with and without anxiety disorders and analyzed data from a 16-year longitudinal fMRI study. I have received my PhD in Developmental Psychology from Leiden University (The Netherlands). My dissertation focused on delineating electrophysiological endophenotypes of social anxiety disorder.

awards.description:

profile_positions.description:
- Leading a Marie Sklodowska-Curie Actions Individual Fellowship on social and neural moderators of the temperament-anxiety association
- Working on project "Growing up together in society"
- Teaching Clinical Psychology in BA1
- Supervision master and bachelor theses
profile_positions.title: Assistant Professor in Clinical Psychology

profile_positions.description: - Leading a Marie Sklodowska-Curie Actions Individual Fellowship on social and neural moderators of the temperament-anxiety association
profile_positions.title: Post-doctoral researcher

profile_positions.description:
- Led several projects on neural and behavioral responses to anxiety-provoking stimuli in children with anxiety disorders
- Analyzed longitudinal data on development of anxiety in children with early-childhood behavioral inhibition, in collaboration with Child Development Lab, University of Maryland
- Coordinated randomized controlled trial testing attention bias modification training
- Led the mega-analysis of 5523 structural MRI scans from 27 different research sites world-wide, focused on anxiety as part of ENIGMA collaboration
o Techniques: (f)MRI, EEG, eye-tracking, skin conductance response, heart rate, behavioral observations, self-report data
profile_positions.title: Post-doctoral researcher

profile_positions.description:
- Led multi-generational family study to delineate psychophysiological endophenotypes of social anxiety disorder
- Initiated an EEG study on social evaluation in high versus low socially anxious students
- Obtained certificate of university teaching qualification
- PhD representative in department of developmental and educational psychology
o Techniques: EEG, heart rate, self-report data
profile_positions.title: PhD student

profile_positions.description:
- EEG pilot studies
- Designing EEG research protocol for Family study
